sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Handwritten letter from Weisse to Schenker, dated August 4, [1914]
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: Weisse reports: his Quintet is now finished; he is in the midst of reading Schenker’s monograph on Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony; repeats his request to have piano lessons with Schenker; and asks his teacher’s advice concerning some songs of his that Lorle Meissner would be interested in singing.
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: Weisse, Hans; Schenker, Heinrich; Quintet; Beethovens Neunte Sinfonie; Beethoven's Ninth Symphony; synthesis; Bopp, Wilhelm; Wiener, Karl von; Violin, Moriz; Meissner, Lorle; Brünauer, Ida; Salzburg

tei:p.tei:hi: Handwritten letter from Weisse to Schenker, dated August 4 [1912]

tei:transcription.tei:p: Vor allem Dank für Ihre letzte liebe Karte The postcard is not known to survive. und die Nachricht, dass der zweite Satz meines Quintetts vollständig fertig ist und[,] wie ich glaube, zugleich das Beste ist[,] was ich bis jetzt gemacht habe! Sehr tiefe Erfindung und gute Synthese.

Dann aber muss ich Ihnen auch sagen, wie sehr ^ich^ mich an der IX. ergötze, die ich Seite für Seite genauest studiere, From this remark one may deduce that this letter was written shortly after the publication of Beethovens Neunte Sinfonie by Universal Edition; copies of the book were dispatched on July 3, 1912. und die wie ich glaube der beste Beweis für die grandiose Lebenskraft Ihrer Theorie, Ihres Systems ist. —

{2} Was Ihre Lehrbücher in sich trugen, in sich selbst aufbauten, entsteht neuerdings hier wie auszwingensdster[?] Notwendigkeit an der [corr from dem] Kunstwerkanalyse. Ihre einmal ausgesprochene Absicht[,] die Brücke zwischen Kunst und Theorie zu schlagen[,] wächst aus dem Bilde ins Wesenhafte! Das ist die idealste Brücke, die bisher einer gebaut hat, und welcher von den Blinden nicht Boden und Geländer zu ertasten vermag – hier helfen dann Götter selbst vergebens!

Ich habe nun den I. Satz der IX. in Angriff genommen und mit grösster Freude die Polemik gegen alle {3} Maulhelden gelesen! Hier möchte ich Ihnen doch sagen, dass es mich gewundert hat, die Wiener–Bopp-Broschüre Wiener-Bopp-Broschüre: presumably the polemical pamphlet written by Moriz Violin, Die Zustände an der k. k. Akademie für Musik und darstellende Kunst: Ein offenes Wort über die Leiter der Anstalt Herren v. Wiener und Bopp (Vienna: M. Violin, 1912) criticizing the sweeping changes—including compulsory staff redundancies and early retirements—at the Vienna Conservatory, instituted by its Director, Wilhelm Bopp, and its President, Karl von Wiener. nicht schärfer und wuchtiger drauf los hauen zu sehen! Ich fürchte dass infolge dessen zu wenig Staub aufgewirbelt wurde und dass der arme Violin gar nicht auf seine Kosten gekommen ist! Auch waren meines Erachtens nach zu wenig Fälle zitiert!

Ich frage mich nochmals wegen der Klavierstunden bei Ihnen an! Weisse had been having piano lessons with Moriz Violin, but was hoping that Schenker would teach him the piano, alongside theory and composition. Für mich bedeutets ein unerhörtes Glück und ich brächte Ihnen dafür Lust und Eifer, Liebe und Fleiss entgegen.

{4} Lorle Meissner| Lorle Meissner, a singer (probably a contralto, and probably based in Vienna). Her name appears on recital programmes in Berlin in the 1910s, and on a flyer listing concerts given at the Musikverein in Vienna in October–November 1921. (We do not know whether Meissner actually performed songs by Weisse; a lieder recital of hers was scheduled for October 25, a week before the première of Weisse’s String Quartet in C, on November 3. A copy of the flyer is preserved in OJ 15/15.) will Lieder von mir singen aber tiefere. Wie wäre mit den Rücker[t] Lieder? Presumably songs already composed by Weisse, but for a high voice. Friedrich Rückert (1788–1866) was a German poet and scholar of Oriental languages; his lyrics were among the most frequently set to music in the Romantic period and the early 20th century.
Morgen spielt Frau Ida Brünauer Ida Brünauer: presumably a relation of the industrialist and Schenker’s long-standing pupil Robert Brünauer. in Salzburg meinem Vater auf Engagement vor!

Nehmen Sie sich bitte meiner Liederbitte ein wenig an und lassen Sie bald von sich etwa hören (auch von Hertzka.) Weisse may may have been hoping that, through his teacher’s contact with Emil Hertzka, Universal Edition might publish some of his music.
In Liebe und Freundschaft ganz Ihr

tei:p.tei:hi: Handwritten letter from Weisse to Schenker, dated August 4 [1912]

tei:translation.tei:p: First of all, I send my thanks for your last, lovely postcard, and also the news that the second movement of my Quintet is completely finished and, so I believe, the best work that I have written to date! Very deep inventiveness, and good synthesis.

Secondly, I must also tell you how much I am captified by your book on the Ninth Symphony, which I am studying most carefully, page by page, and which I believe to be the best proof for the magnificent life-force of your theory, your system.

{2} What your theoretical works embraced in themselves is reborn here, as though of the most convincing necessity for the analysis of works of art. Your marked intention to bridge the gap between art and theory grows out of the picture into something significant! That is the most ideal bridge that has yet been built, and one whose floor and railings will be inaccessible to the blind—here the gods themselves will be powerless!

I have tackled the first movement of the Ninth and read with great joy the polemic against all {3} loudmouths! Here I should like, however, to say that I was surprised that the Wiener–Bopp pamphlet did not deal with them more sharply and forcefully! I fear that, as a consequence, too little dirt will have been stirred up and that poor Violin will in no way be able to recoup his losses. Also, it is my opinion that too few examples were actually quoted!
I ask once more about having piano lessons with you! For me, this would mean an unimaginable joy, for which I would bring to you my enthusiasm, determination, love, and industry.
{4} Lorle Meissner| would like to sing Lieder of mine, but ones written for a low voice. What would you say to the Rücker[t] songs?
Tomorrow, Mrs Ida Brünauer is auditioning in Salzburg to my father, in the hope of getting a part!
Please consider my request regarding the songs, and let me hear something about you (and also about Herztka) soon.
In love and friendship, Yours truly,
